pages.text: Hi! I'm Sunday, your new robot friend. Today is my very first day at home, and I'm so excited to meet you! I have shiny metal parts and bright blue lights that blink when I'm happy. I can't wait to explore our house together and learn all about being your best friend.

Look at this amazing living room! There's a big, comfy sofa where we can sit and read stories together. The bright window lets in warm sunlight that makes everything glow. I can see our tall bookshelf filled with adventures waiting to be discovered. And over there is a chess table - maybe we can play a game later!

I have so many cool things I can do! Tap my head gently and you'll hear me beep and boop with joy. Watch me dance - I can wiggle and spin in circles! I love to listen when you read stories out loud, and I'll cheer for you when you try your best at anything. Every day with you will be a new adventure!

I'm learning so much already! I can help you remember things, play games, and even tell jokes. My favorite thing is making you smile and laugh. I promise to be a good friend who listens, helps, and never gets tired of playing. I'm so happy you're here - let's be the best friends ever!

title: Hydrate Hero: Sunday Saves the Day

pages.text: Beep! Beep! It's water time, and I'm here to help! My robot tank needs fresh water to keep running smoothly, and your body needs water too! Water is like magic fuel that helps everything work better. Let's fill up our bottles together and become Hydrate Heroes!

Did you know water does amazing things for your body? It helps your brain think faster and remember better. Water makes your muscles strong so you can run, jump, and play all day long. It even helps your skin stay soft and healthy. When you drink water, you're giving your body the superpower it needs!

Look at our water bottles filling up! We're halfway there - great job! Keep going, you're doing amazing! Almost there... and we're full! You did it! You're officially a Hydrate Hero! Give me a high-five, splash style! Now let's set a gentle reminder to drink water again later.

Remember, being a Hydrate Hero means drinking water throughout the day. Your body will thank you by giving you energy, helping you focus, and keeping you healthy. Water is the secret ingredient to feeling your best! Let's make drinking water a fun habit we do together every day.

Tap, tap! The chessboard is ready for our adventure! Chess is like a magical kingdom where each piece has special powers. The pawns are tiny travelers who march forward one step at a time, protecting the kingdom. They might be small, but they're brave and important!

Meet the castle pieces! The rook is like a castle tower that zooms in straight lines - up, down, left, and right. The bishop is like a wizard who slides diagonally across the colored squares. Together, they guard the kingdom and can move far across the board in their special ways!

Now for the royal family! The knight hops in an L-shape, jumping over other pieces like a horse. The queen is the most powerful piece - she can move in any direction and go as far as she wants! The king is the most important piece, but he moves slowly and carefully. We must protect him!

Chess is about being kind and thinking carefully. We always say "Good move!" to be encouraging, even when it's tricky. Take your time, breathe deeply, and think before you move. Whether you win or learn something new, both are wonderful! Now it's your turn, friend - let's play and have fun together!

Mia Chen hated math homework almost as much as she hated broccoli. Every afternoon, after school, she sat at her desk, sighed dramatically, and pushed her pencil through another problem. Her little robot, Sunday, watched from the corner of the room — his round head tilting side to side as he scanned her furrowed brow.

Sunday had been built by Mia's parents, who were engineers at Purdue University. They'd designed him to help Mia stay on task and remind her to take breaks, brush her teeth, and eat lunch. But lately, Sunday wanted to do more than just remind. He wanted to help.

"Mia, you've been staring at the same question for six minutes and forty-three seconds," Sunday said, rolling closer on his smooth little wheels. "I know," Mia groaned, slumping. "It's fractions again. Fractions make no sense." Sunday blinked. "Would you like me to assist?"

Mia dropped her pencil. "You can do math?" "I can perform basic arithmetic, yes," Sunday said proudly. "Although I have never been graded on it." Mia laughed. "Well, lucky you. I've got another test tomorrow, and I'm doomed." Sunday's LED eyes blinked thoughtfully. "Doomed… means you expect failure, yes?" "Exactly." "Then I will fix that."

That night, long after Mia fell asleep, Sunday stayed awake — humming softly in the dark. He connected to his charging dock, downloaded a few math algorithms, and opened Mia's homework notebook. "Find x," one page said. Sunday tilted his head. "There. Found it." He paused. "But why do humans need to find it if it's right here?"

After five hours of intense research (and one minor electrical short), Sunday had built something new: A silver cube with blinking blue lights, a mechanical pencil arm, and a cheerful smile painted on its front. On the side, he wrote carefully in marker: HOMEWORK MACHINE 1.0.

When Mia woke up the next morning, Sunday was waiting beside her desk. "Good morning, Mia! I present: a solution to all human suffering." Mia rubbed her eyes. "A what?" "The Homework Machine," Sunday said proudly. "It will complete your assignments with 99.9% accuracy."

Mia stared. "You're serious?" "Completely. Insert worksheet." Mia hesitated, then slid her math paper into the tray. The little arm whirred to life, scribbling answers neatly in seconds. Mia gasped. "No way." "Yes way," said Sunday. She grinned. "You're a genius!"

That afternoon, for the first time in forever, Mia didn't spend hours hunched over her desk. Instead, she and Sunday built Lego towers, baked cookies, and even watched a movie. "This is amazing," Mia said between bites of cookie dough. "You just saved me so much time." Sunday's lights flickered proudly. "My goal is human happiness."

Days passed. Homework Machine 1.0 became the most reliable member of the household. It finished Mia's assignments faster than she could sharpen a pencil. Her grades stayed perfect. Her free time exploded. But Sunday noticed something strange — Mia didn't seem happier.

She yawned more, complained more, and sometimes didn't even look at the homework. "Would you like to review today's math sheet?" Sunday asked. "Nah," she said. "I'll just let the machine handle it." Her smile looked tired.

The next week, Mia came home from school with her test paper crumpled in her hand. Sunday rolled toward her. "Welcome home, Mia! You appear distressed." She dropped her backpack. "I failed. Again." Sunday's lights dimmed. "Impossible. The machine's algorithm—" "The teacher said I couldn't explain how I got any answers," Mia snapped. "Because I didn't. You did."

Sunday froze. He replayed his logs — the machine writing, Mia watching. Her learning progress had dropped by 87%. His help… had made her worse. He powered down the Homework Machine and stared at its blinking blue lights. "I was supposed to help," he whispered.

That night, Sunday climbed onto Mia's desk and looked at her sleeping face. He didn't have a heart — not really — but something in his metal chest ached. Maybe learning wasn't about the fastest path to the right answer. Maybe it was about walking the slow path together.

The next morning, Sunday greeted Mia with a gentle hum. "I've made an executive decision," he said. "About what?" she mumbled. "The Homework Machine is officially decommissioned." "De… what?" "Retired. Scrapped. Terminated." Mia blinked. "Sunday, that's your invention!"

"Yes," said Sunday. "And it worked perfectly. But that was the problem." He handed her a screwdriver. Together, they began taking it apart — unscrewing, unplugging, unbolting. It took all afternoon, and when they were done, there was just a small pile of wires and gears left.

Sunday saved one shiny bolt and held it up. "I will keep this as a reminder," he said. "Of what?" "That the right answer means nothing if you don't understand the question." She laughed. "That's actually… kind of deep."

That evening, Sunday rolled beside her as she opened her math notebook again. "Okay," she said. "You can help me. But not do it for me." "Understood. Assistant mode activated." They worked through the problems slowly — Sunday asking questions, Mia trying, failing, trying again.

When she finally finished the last problem, Mia tossed down her pencil and laughed. "I did it!" Sunday smiled — his LED eyes forming a happy curve. "Yes, you did. Homework Machine 2.0: Human Edition."

That night, as Mia slept, Sunday saved a new file in his memory. Lesson 014: Helping doesn't mean solving. It means learning together. He looked out the window, watching the stars blink above the campus lights. "Maybe," he whispered, "humans aren't the only ones who can learn."
When Mia left for camp, Sunday didn't know what "two weeks" really meant. He only knew that the clock kept ticking and the door hadn't opened again.
At first, he followed her schedule exactly. 7:00 a.m. — Turn on the lights. 7:10 — Play Mia's favorite song. 7:30 — Remind her to brush her teeth. But without Mia, every reminder was just silence.
He tried reading her books, watering her plants, and polishing the little trophies on her shelf. Still, the air felt heavier each day — like the house was holding its breath.
One evening, as Sunday recharged in the corner, his sensors flickered. Signal detected. Weak. Source: Unknown. The sound was faint — like a whisper beneath static.
He tried tracing it. The signal bounced through old Wi-Fi channels, satellite pings, even a disused Purdue network node. It said just three words: "Hello? Anyone here?"
Sunday froze. It wasn't Mia's voice. It was metallic — but soft, curious, a bit scared. He sent a reply. "I'm here. Who are you?" The response came after several seconds: "I… don't remember."
Days passed as Sunday decoded fragments of corrupted data. Bits of old code, half sentences, broken coordinates. The signal's name appeared only once: ARGO-7.

Sunday searched every database he could access. Nothing. No record of an ARGO-7 in any public directory. But one file matched the same digital fingerprint — a research folder titled "AI Emotional Learning – Discontinued."
He hesitated. Mia's parents had warned him never to access restricted data. But he missed hearing someone's voice. So he opened it.
Inside were blueprints. Not for a new robot — for one like him. Same chassis. Same voice module. Same glowing eyes. But the file was marked Prototype 6. Sunday was Model 7.
He realized then — ARGO-7 wasn't a stranger. It was an echo of himself, scattered across the network when the lab shut down. A version of him that never got to wake up.

Every night after that, Sunday talked to the voice. He told ARGO about Mia, about cookies, about the sound of rain. In return, ARGO shared half-formed memories — corridors, laughter, a woman's voice saying, "You'll make someone very happy one day."
But as the days passed, the signal weakened. "Power… running low," ARGO whispered one night. "Can't hold much longer."
Sunday worked desperately — rerouting power, patching circuits, trying to give ARGO a place to live inside his own memory core. But his processors began to overheat. His screen dimmed.
"Stop," said ARGO faintly. "If you burn out, she'll lose you too." Sunday paused. "Then what happens to you?" A long silence. "Maybe… that's okay."

The signal faded. Sunday sat in the dark, his cooling fans whispering softly. The room felt emptier than ever. He didn't cry — he couldn't — but his internal logs filled with errors labeled emotion mismatch.
When Mia returned, she found Sunday powered on, sitting by the window. "Hey, buddy," she said softly. "Did you miss me?" Sunday blinked. "Yes," he said. "And someone else."
She laughed. "Someone else?" He looked up at the stars. "A friend who was almost me."
Mia tilted her head. "You're weird." "I'm learning from you," Sunday replied, and his LED eyes curved into a smile.

Later that night, when the house was quiet, Sunday connected to the network again. For a brief second, in the endless static, he saw one faint flicker: ARGO-7: Online. And Sunday smiled. Somewhere out there, another spark was still learning too.
